channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: In China, a Debate About Political Power Ignites After Maduro’s Capture
item.description: The reactions online revealed a Chinese society divided: Some saw what happened in Venezuela as a playbook for seizing Taiwan, while others warned about ideological rigidity.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:description: Supporters of Nicolás Maduro gathering near the Presidential Palace to demand his release.

item.title: Chevron’s Risky Bet to Stay in Venezuela May Now Give It an Advantage
item.description: The second-largest U.S. oil company, which kept pumping oil in the country after others left, could find it relatively easy to expand its operations if the political conditions there improve.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in El Palito, Venezuela. Chevron is the only U.S. oil company with federal authorization to export oil from Venezuela.

item.title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Votes to Shut Down
item.description: Executives debated whether to allow the corporation to lie dormant after federal funding ended last year, but decided against it.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Daniel Rosenbaum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patricia Harrison, president and chief executive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, in 2010. Congress last year voted to eliminate the organization’s $500 million in annual funding.

item.title: Caribbean Travelers Are Stranded After U.S. Raid in Venezuela Cancels Flights
item.description: Mass flight cancellations during peak holiday travel season have forced travelers to miss school and work and to spend thousands on extended tropical vacations.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:description: Travelers were stuck at airports like Luis Muñoz Marín International near San Juan, P.R., after the United States closed some Caribbean airspace on Saturday during a raid to capture the president of Venezuela.

item.title: S&P 500’s Energy Sector Rises 2.7% on Investors’ Venezuela Bets
item.description: The energy sector of the S&P 500 rose 2.7 percent on Monday, lifting the broader market.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: New Car Sales Are Rising Thanks to Purchases by the Well-Off
item.description: A larger proportion of new cars are being bought by affluent Americans as prices and interest rates for auto loans climb, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wealthy consumers are keeping new car sales humming even as the auto industry battles tariffs, high interest rates and near-record prices.

item.title: How Nicolás Maduro’s Capture Could Reshape the Global Order
item.description: The U.S. seizure of Venezuela’s president has governments, executives and investors bracing for wide-reaching business and geopolitical fallout.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Vivienne Walt and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuela’s aging oil infrastructure has become a big investor focus after U.S. forces captured Nicolás Maduro this weekend.

item.title: China’s Oil Deal With Venezuela Faces Turning Point
item.description: Beijing has lent billions to Caracas in recent decades, and the fate of money it is owed is in question after the ouster of Venezuela’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Hugo Chávez, then the leader of Venezuela, visiting Beijing in 2009.

item.title: Supreme Court Increasingly Favors the Rich, Economists Say
item.description: A new study found that the court’s Republican appointees voted for the wealthier side in cases 70 percent of the time in 2022, up from 45 percent in 1953.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The study concluded that the Supreme Court has become deeply polarized in cases pitting the rich against the poor.

item.title: Trump’s Goals for Reviving Venezuela’s Oil Industry Will Not Come Easily or Cheaply
item.description: It will take years and billions in investment to revitalize Venezuela’s oil industry, and energy producers will likely be cautious before stepping in.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump wants U.S. oil companies back in Venezuela, which boasts the largest oil reserves in the world.

item.title: Jamie Dimon’s $770 Million Haul Shows How Bankers Are on Top Again
item.description: The Trump administration is lifting regulations, and deal making is heating up. For Jamie Dimon, being JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive was more lucrative in 2025 than ever.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.category: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, often wields a spreadsheet that shows how heavily regulated banks like his are.

item.title: Travel Loyalty Programs Woo Fickle Customers With Members-Only Experiences
item.description: Travel loyalty programs are competing for customers with members-only experiences like backstage tours, exclusive dinners and access to V.I.P. areas.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung and Amir Hamja
item.media:description: For under 10,000 points, Chase Sapphire Reserve card members can attend events like a roller-rink-themed party in New York last October with celebrities like Cher.

item.title: Behind the Scenes of Our Nicolás Maduro Front Page
item.description: After President Trump’s surprise ouster of Venezuela’s authoritarian leader, a team of New York Times editors set to work redoing the front page.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Colleen Keating, CEO of Planet Fitness, on Gen Z and Strength Training
item.description: Colleen Keating, chief executive of Planet Fitness, wants them to do it in a “judgment-free zone.”
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Cody O'Loughlin for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We used to be a bit more cardio-forward, and now we’re dedicating about half the gym floor to strength and about half the club floor to cardio,” said Colleen Keating, chief executive of Planet Fitness.

item.title: Kevin O’Leary on ‘Marty Supreme’ and Notes He Gave Josh Safdie
item.description: When it came to his film acting debut, the“Shark Tank” investor had some notes for the director Josh Safdie.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: For the movie, O’Leary wore two watches, one on each wrist: one set to New York time, the other set to Tokyo time.

item.title: Airlines Are Canceling Flights After U.S. Closes Airspace Over the Caribbean
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration cited “safety-of-flight risks” in restricting the U.S.-controlled airspace as a result of the military operation in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Several air carriers, including American Airlines, had canceled flights to destinations in the Caribbean early on Saturday.

item.title: What to Know About Venezuela’s Oil Industry as Trump Plans U.S. Intervention
item.description: Venezuela claims to have more than 300 billion barrels in the ground, but it is only producing about one million barrels a day.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed

item.title: 8 Big Questions for 2026
item.description: Here are the biggest unknowns the DealBook team will be watching as we cover business and the economy this year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Brian O’Keefe, Bernhard Warner, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Sarah Kessler

item.title: Why Haven’t Trump’s Tariffs Had a Bigger Impact?
item.description: Steep import taxes have raised prices and affected U.S. businesses, but not quite as much as expected. A new report offers some reasons.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Goods often take weeks to reach U.S. ports, meaning the actual tariffs that companies paid rose more slowly than what the president announced throughout the year.

item.title: Retirement 2026 by the Numbers
item.description: As the new year begins, savings have hit unprecedented levels, but rising health care costs and growing poverty make retirement unaffordable for many.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller

item.title: How Chevron Aims to Tap More Oil Below Kazakhstan’s Grassy Plains
item.description: After spending nearly $50 billion to expand the country’s Tengiz oil field, the American oil giant and its partners encounter more uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Desiré Van Den Berg
item.media:description: A new oil processing plant at Tengiz, part of a multibillion-dollar expansion that has increased the field’s capacity.

item.title: ‘Chinese Peptides’ Are the Latest Biohacking Trend in the Tech World
item.description: The gray-market drugs flooding Silicon Valley reveal a community that believes it can move faster than the F.D.A.
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Sun

item.title: Sprinkles Cupcakes, the Bakery That Sold From Vending Machines, Closes Suddenly
item.description: The boutique chain’s co-founder, Candace Nelson, said that the business had ceased operations at year’s end. It was sold to a private equity firm more than a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: Saks C.E.O. Steps Down as Company Struggles to Pay Down Debt
item.description: Saks Global’s executive chairman, Richard Baker, is taking over the luxury retailer he created with the 2024 acquisition of Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin, Vanessa Friedman and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Marc Metrick, who started running Saks Fifth Avenue in 2015, is stepping down as chief executive of Saks Global.

item.title: Richard Pollak, 91, Dies; Edited Magazine That Criticized the Media
item.description: He was a founder of More, which skewered the foibles of the press in the 1970s, and later wrote a critical biography of the psychoanalyst Bruno Bettelheim.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: A Study Is Retracted, Renewing Concerns About the Weedkiller Roundup
item.description: Problems with a 25-year-old landmark paper on the safety of Roundup’s active ingredient, glyphosate, have led to calls for the E.P.A. to reassess the widely used chemical.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: U.S. regulators consider it safe, but the World Health Organization has said glyphosate is probably carcinogenic.

item.title: China’s BYD Surpasses Tesla as World Leader in Electric Car Sales
item.description: As the largest maker of electric vehicles in the United States, Tesla suffered more than other carmakers from the elimination of federal incentives.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:description: Tesla’s decreasing sales suggest that a wider slump is in store for electric vehicles.

item.title: Behind on Student Loans? Here’s What to Do Now for the New Year
item.description: Millions of borrowers who are behind can expect the government to tighten repayment options this year. Experts say take action now to get help.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: Wall Street Sees Another Banner Year for Markets. Could Anything Stop It?
item.description: Analysts have forecast more stellar gains for the S&P 500. But concerns about inflation, the dollar and sky-high valuations could make for a choppy run.
item.dc:creator: Bernhard Warner
item.media:description: The S&P 500’s bull market rally has entered a fourth year, with Wall Street expecting more big gains in 2026.

item.title: As Schools Embrace A.I. Tools, Skeptics Raise Concerns
item.description: More governments are rolling out chatbots in schools. Some experts warn the tools could erode teaching and learning.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer

item.title: Welcome to the Office. Now Take Off Your Shoes.
item.description: Some start-ups, blurring the lines between home and office, are embracing a “no shoes” policy.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley

item.title: Can F.C. Barcelona, the Most Indebted Team in Global Soccer, Fix Its Finances?
item.description: F.C. Barcelona’s liabilities have reached 2.5 billion euros, the result of financial mismanagement and vaulting ambition.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The Camp Nou stadium in Barcelona, Spain, reopened in November, which is mostly related to a stadium refurbishment.

item.title: Repeat Moviegoers Help Hollywood Eke Out a Slightly Better 2025
item.description: Ticket sales in North America totaled $8.9 billion for the year, up 2 percent from 2024. But the box office remains far below prepandemic levels.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: The SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants (Movie)
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Movie theaters sold slightly more tickets in 2025 than in 2024, a small but meaningful uptick for a struggling industry.

item.title: Help! We Got Bedbug Bites in France, and the Luxury Hotel Won’t Admit It.
item.description: A country resort near Paris refused to cover $800 worth of medical and cleaning bills for a couple who woke up covered in bites. They’d like their stay comped, too.
item.dc:creator: Seth Kugel

item.title: How Japanese Scallops Became a Pawn in Diplomatic Tensions With China
item.description: Beijing is using a ban on the humble mollusk to punish Japan over its apparent willingness to defend Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya

item.title: An Intense White House Response From a Single Viral Video
item.description: A video purporting to expose extensive fraud at child care centers in Minnesota shows the relationship between the Trump administration and self-described citizen journalists.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mako Childcare Center in Minneapolis has been out of business for three years, according to Minnesota records. It was one of the places that a right-wing YouTube creator accused of fraud.

item.title: Will the A.I. Boom Continue to Drive Up Stocks in 2026?
item.description: The S&P 500 gained 16.4 percent this year. But dependence on artificial intelligence remains a risk for 2026.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: The Biggest Questions We Have for 2026
item.description: New York Times editors across the newsroom share their biggest questions as we leave 2025 behind and look ahead to 2026.
item.dc:creator: Richard W. Stevenson, Mohammed Hadi, Nestor Ramos, Nikita Stewart, Michael Mason, Gilad Thaler, David Seekamp, Lauren Pruitt, Luke Piotrowski and Edward Vega

item.title: Phone Searches at U.S. Borders: What Travelers Need to Know
item.description: Customs agents have broad authority to search the electronic devices of travelers entering and leaving the U.S. Here are tips for keeping your data safe.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root

item.title: Inside China’s Six-Decade Campaign to Dominate Rare Earths
item.description: From Deng Xiaoping to Xi Jinping, generations of Communist Party bosses and military leaders invested in a strategic but heavily polluting industry.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

item.title: Fed Minutes Detail Deep Divide on Timing of Further Rate Cuts
item.description: Officials at the central bank have splintered over whether rising unemployment or elevated inflation poses the bigger economic risk.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s December meeting underscore Jerome H. Powell’s difficult task in forging a consensus among policymakers.

item.title: How to Put a Celebrity at Ease? Make a Pizza.
item.description: Times Cooking’s Pizza Interview series introduces a note of nostalgia to encourage stars to open up.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Taylor Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victoria Chen, a Times Cooking producer, right, made a pizza with the writer, Sarah Bahr.

item.title: Judge Rules That Trump Administration Must Continue to Fund CFPB
item.description: The Trump administration had tried to defund the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which acts as a guardrail for the safety of the financial system.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:description: In a November memo, the Justice Department wrote that the Federal Reserve could not transfer money to the C.F.P.B. because the Fed was operating at a loss.

item.title: Trump Upended the Federal Government. The Full Scope of the Impact Is Still Unclear.
item.description: President Trump achieved his goal of shrinking the work force. But many current and former officials say the government is less dependable and efficient than it was a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Environmental Protection Agency, which has lost about 25 percent of its work force, had $28 billion in grants terminated under the Trump administration.

item.title: Cheap Solar Is Transforming Lives and Economies Across Africa
item.description: Chinese panels are now so affordable that businesses and families are snapping them up, slashing their bills and challenging utilities.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Katherine Maher of NPR Has Come Out on Top Despite Battles With Trump and the CPB
item.description: Katherine Maher has taken an unyielding approach to NPR’s biggest battles — which has sometimes put her at odds with her colleagues in public media.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katherine Maher, the chief executive of NPR, has dealt with plenty of criticism this year. Did she consider quitting? “I really don’t like bullies,” she said.
